newsitem.title: JAPAN: Arafat blames Israel for peace process standstill.
newsitem.headline: Arafat blames Israel for peace process standstill.

text.p: Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on Thursday blamed Israel for the standstill in the Middle East peace process, calling its attitude a breach of an international agreement.
"This is not a bilateral agreement between the PLO and Israel but an international agreement," Arafat told U.S. cable television network CNN in an interview.

Arafat's four-day visit to Tokyo, which began on Tuesday, comes just one week after his landmark meeting and handshake with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. "The meeting was positive, but the results up to now are zero," Arafat said.

Arafat avoided commenting on his impression of Netanyahu, saying he respected the democratic choice of the Israeli people, but stressed that the Middle East peace process was not a matter of negotiation with Netanyahu.
"We're not asking for the moon. We're only asking for an international resolution to be implemented," he said.
Arafat, who in January became the first democratically chosen Palestinian leader, is touring the world appealing for pressure on the Israeli leader.

The Palestinians want implementation of the 1993 Oslo agreement on an Israeli troop redeployment in Hebron and other areas of the West Bank, and the opening of a passage for Palestinians to travel between the West Bank and Gaza.
Israel has stressed that self-rule in the Gaza Strip and West Bank cannot go ahead unless its security needs are satisfied.
Asked about Israeli plans to build new housing units in the disputed area, Arafat said: "That is a clear breach of what has been agreed upon."
He repeated his call for the international community, particularly Japan, to push forward the peace process.
Arafat was due to meet Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto later on Thursday.
Japan has diplomatic relations with Israel but does not officially recognise the Palestine Liberation Organisation.
